Single ethylene molecular insertion as a probe into the nature of the active species in MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts Chifeng Zhong a ⁎ Bingquan Mao b a Dongguan Cleaner production Center, Dongguan University of Technology, Dongguan, Guangdong 523808, China Dongguan Cleaner production Center Dongguan University of Technology Dongguan Guangdong 523808 China b Beijing Research Institute of Chemical Industry, SINOPEC, Beijing 100013, China Beijing Research Institute of Chemical Industry SINOPEC Beijing 100013 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 0769 22862601; fax: +86 0769 22861980. Graphical abstract The chain end groups formed by “one” ethylene molecule insertion were studied by 13C NMR. These results disclose differences of catalytic properties between the three classes of active species in MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst. The propylene-ethylene copolymers with a very small amount of ethylene (from 0.01 to 1.8mol%) obtained with different catalyst systems at 100°C or 120°C were characterized by 13C NMR. The chain end group n-propyl formed through the chain transfer reaction of species to alkylaluminum following “one” ethylene molecule insertion was detected in these copolymers of low molecular weight. 13C NMR chain end group analysis of these copolymers implied that most of syndiotactic species in the MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts would be “dormant” for propylene insertion while highly isotactic species would remain highly active for propylene insertion when these two species were inserted by “one” ethylene molecule. For isotactoid species occasional “one” ethylene molecule insertions remarkably slowed down propagation of propylene. The active species could be divided into three classes according to their behavior following “one” ethylene molecule insertion, which fit Busico [1] three-state model of active species to a great degree. The chain end group ethyl (Et′) formed by chain transfer reactions by alkylaluminum at “one” ethylene molecule insertion followed by a 2-1-last-insertion was also detected by 13C NMR. Thus, the fraction of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit was estimated to be in the 3–6mol% range for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diester-silane catalyst while for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diether catalyst the content of such the fraction was ca. 7–9mol%. 13C NMR analysis indicated that a large part of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites revived by “one” ethylene insertion were still “dormant” for propylene insertion at high polymerization temperature. Keywords Supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst Propylene Ethylene Temperature Active species Agostic interacion 1 Introduction It is well known that the MgCl2-supported titanium catalyst systems which combined with the lewis bases such as diesters, alkoxysilanes and 1,3-diethers as internal or external donors, are the most commonly used in the current industrial processes. These catalysts are known to contain different classes of active species; as a result, they afford polypropylenes which are complicated mixtures of highly isotactic, poorly isotactic (“isotactoid”), and syndiotactic sequences, at least in part chemically linked to form stereoblock chains [1–3]. The active species in these heterogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts are still an area of intense interest [4–7]. In the past two decades, modified and extended versions of Corradini's model of active species were elaborated by Busico group [1] and Scordamaglia group [8]. The models of three active species are showed in Fig. 1 . According to Busico's suggestion [1], ligands L1 and L2 can also be Lewis base or Al-alkyl molecules, and their coordination can be labile, possible resulting in a reversible interconversion of species (a), (b), and (c). Propylene/ethylene-[1-13C] copolymerization methods have been applied by Busico group to measure precisely the regioselectivity in propylene polymerization with the “simple” TiCl4MgCl2 catalyst (without any donor) [9] and with a diester-based and a diether-based catalyst systems [10,11]. By using ethylene-[1-13C] in the place of ethylene at natural isotopic abundance, the sensitivity of the 13C NMR analysis is increased by a factor of 50, and the threshold for the detection of the regiodefects is lowered correspondingly (from 0.1–1.0 to 0.002–0.02mol%, respectively) [9–13]. Stopped-flow propylene-ethylene copolymerization was applied by Terano group to elucidate the essential characteristics of copolymerization [14]. Hexene/ethylene copolymerization method had been applied by Fan group to investigate the effect of ethylene on the distribution of active centers [6]. In recent 10 years, the propylene polymerization at the higher temperature, such as 100°C or 120°C, was reported by Kojoh group [15] and our group [16–18]. It was reported that the PP prepared with Et3Al as cocatalyt at 100°C or 120°C, was a random copolymer with a very small amount of ethylene unit. It indicated that the decomposition reaction of Et3Al occurred and the resulting small amount of ethylene was polymerized in the polymer chain [15–18]. In Busico's studies [9–11], (isobutyl)3Al was used as the catalyst because the copolymers they studied would be contaminated by the ethylene liberated by Et3Al. However, the decomposition of Et3Al takes place randomly during entire the polymerization process at 100°C or 120°C and the concentration of ethylene round the active species may be extremely low if the concentration of Et3Al is low enough. Thus, it is possible to study the behavior of different active species following “one” ethylene molecule insertion, which cannot be imagined when ethylene gas is fed. Due to the small size of the ethylene molecule, one may assume that it do not “feel” the different steric hindrance with different active species or with growing chains with a last-inserted 1,2- or 2,1-propylene unit [13]. Moreover, the relatively low molecular weights obtained at high polymerization temperature make possible a comprehensive analysis of chain end groups, and then the fundamental issue of the relationship between the classes of chain end groups and chain stereoregularity and the distribution of ethylene unit in the chain can be addressed. In this paper, the polymerizations of propylene at 100°C or 120°C were performed with four MgCl2-supported titanium catalyst systems including the “simple” TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst, followed by the characterization using 13C NMR, gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and temperature rising elution fractionation (TREF). On the base of these data, we reported the significant difference in the chain end structures between coPPs prepared with the different catalyst systems. Furthermore, the effect of three active species on the distributions of ethylene unit along the polypropylene chain was discussed. Busico group have investigated in detail a number of highly regioselective catalyst systems including metallocenes and heterogeneous MgCl2-supported catalysts by Propylene/ethylene-[1-13C] copolymerization method [9–13]. They paid much attention to the regiomistakes produced by ethylene-[1-13C] insertion in the polymer chain while our researches will focus on study of the chain end groups of PP. Our results provide a new insight into the behavior of the catalytic species. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The catalyst TiCl4/MgCl2/BMMF containing 9,9-bis(methoxymethyl)fluorine (BMMF) as the internal donor, the donor-free catalysts TiCl4/MgCl2 were prepared according to references [16]. The catalyst TiCl4/MgCl2/DNBP containing dibutyl phthalate (DNBP) as the internal donor was prepared according to reference [18]. Catalyst A stands for TiCl4/MgCl2/BMMF (BMMF as an internal donor); catalyst B stands for TiCl4/MgCl2-BMMF (BMMF as an external donor); catalyst C stands for TiCl4/MgCl2/DNBP-cylohexanemethyl dimethyloxysilane (CHMDMS); catalyst D stands for TiCl4/MgCl2. The contents of titanium in the catalyst B, C and D were 2.34wt%, 2.6wt% and 2.34wt%, respectively. The contents of titanium in the catalyst A for Run 1, Run 2 and Run 3 were 2.16wt%, 1.9wt% and 1.9wt%, respectively. 2.2 Propylene slurry polymerization In a 400ml reactor previously purged with nitrogen and propylene, 150ml anhydrous n-decane was added. Then, a prescribed amount of catalyst and cocatalysts were added at room temperature with a vigorous stir. The reactor was rapidly raised (ca. 5min) to desired polymerization temperature. Polymerization was carried out under pressure in the range 0.11–0.13MPa. The reaction time was 1h. The polymer was washed by HCl/alcohol (5/95 v/v), and filtered and dried. 2.3 Polymer characterization Polypropylene (PP) was fractionated with boiling heptane by conventional methods. The fractions of boiling-heptane-insoluble were termed by isotactic polypropylene (iPP) and the fractions of boiling-heptane-soluble were termed by atactic polypropylene (aPP). The molecular weight of PPs was measured by a Waters gel permeation chromatograph Alliance GPCV 2000. The weight-average and number-average molecular weight (M w and M n , respectively) of polymers were calculated on the basis of a polystyrene standard calibration. 13C NMR spectra of PPs were recorded with a Bruker DMX 400 spectrometer operating at 100.6MHz, on 10–20mg/ml solutions in deuterated dichlorobenzene at 110°C. Condition (all the PPs except for iPP2 and iPP3,): 10mm probe; acquisition time, 5s; relaxation time, 10s; numbers of scans 5000. Condition (iPP2 and iPP3): 5mm probe; acquisition time, 2s; relaxation time, 2s; numbers of scans 20,000. Chemical shifts were referred to isolated methylenes at 30.0ppm. The thermal analysis was carried out by means of DSC (Perkin-Elmer DSC-7). The PP obtained with Run 9 was fractionated using the temperature-rising elution procedure in our preparative TREF equipment. The fractionation process was described as follows: 1wt% PP9 sample was first dissolved in 1,2,4-trimethybenzene at 140°C, and then introduced into the elution column of TREF under the N2. The process to precipitate polypropylene onto the surface of the support was finished by cooling the polymer solution from 140°C to 25°C in 85h. The elution step was carried out with trimethylbenzene at 25°C (PP9(1)), 80°C (PP9(2)), 100°C (PP9(3)), 105°C (PP9(4)), 110°C (PP9(5)), 120°C (PP9(6)), and 140°C (PP9(7)), respectively. The recovery of all the fractions was 98.4%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Three classes of active species The propylene polymerizations over four MgCl2-supported titanium catalyst systems including the “simple” TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst, diether-based system and diester-based systems were performed at 100°C or 120°C without addition of hydrogen. The results concerning catalyst system, catalyst amount, polymer isotacticity index, and catalyst activity were showed in Table 1 . The results of polymer concerning molecular weight from GPC, the [mmmm] pentad content and average isotactic sequence lengths (MRLs) [19] from 13C NMR were showed in Table 2 . The 13C NMR spectra of selected PPs were showed in Fig. 2 . Although these results were presented in our previous papers [16–18], full details of chain end groups and microstructure would be first discussed in this paper. Since the molecular weight of these PPs was low enough, the terminal groups of these polypropylenes were also detected in 13C NMR spectra. The structures of chain end groups were showed in Scheme 1 and the carbon peaks associated with chain end groups were assigned according to the reports [20–24]. The chemical shifts and the peak assignments and the calculated results were listed in Tables 3 and 4 . It is generally accepted that the mechanisms of chain transfer reactions in propylene polymerization without hydrogen can be classified into the following three types, which are caused by (i) alkylaluminum as a cocatalyst, (ii) elimination of β-H in the chain ends, (iii) propylene monomer [22–24]. Chadwick group [25] reported at relatively low hydrogen concentrations, (monomer-assisted) chain transfer via β-H abstraction may play a significant role in propylene polymerization at 70°C with a diether as an external donor. Liquid propylene was used in Chadwick's report while propylene gas under atmospheric pressure was used in our slurry polymerization experiments. It indicated the concentration of propylene of Chadwick's report was much higher than that of our experiments. Furthermore, the concentration of Et3Al of our experiments was higher than that of Chadwick's report. Kojoh group [23,24] reported the chain transfer reaction by Et3Al (or other alkylaluminum) at 1,2-insertion sites occurred predominantly among all the possible chain transfer reaction under the slurry polymerization condition at high polymerization temperature (100°C). This phenomenon can be interpreted as a much higher ratio of alkylaluminum to propylene and a higher activation energy for chain transfer reaction by alkylaluminum. The experiment condition in this paper was nearly similar to that in the Kojoh's report. As showed in Table 4, the chain end groups of the iPP1 of Run1 consisted of isobutyl group (i-Bu) only because Me3Al instead of Et3Al was used as the cocatalyst. The chain end groups of the iPP3, iPP4, iPP6, iPP7, and iPP8 consisted of ethyl group (Et) (derived from initiation reaction) and i-Bu (derived from chain transfer to alkylaluminum). Obviously, the number of Et terminals should be equal to the number of i-Bu terminals. But the number of right-end terminals (Et) generally appeared to exceed the numbers of left-end terminals (i-Bu) by 0–54%. This phenomenon was also reported by Sacchi group [26]. This can be explained by the errors introduced by the integrals of signals of low intensity of different carbons [26]. The peak at 22.84ppm of chain end group vinylidene (Vd) showed in Scheme 1 was not found in all the PPs obtained at 100°C. The contents of i-Bu in PP9(2), PP9(3), PP9(5) and iPP8, which were obtained when “TMA-depleted” methylaluminoxane (MMAO) was added during the polymerization process, were found to be higher than those of Et. MMAO that contained no or very little TMA is not an efficient activator, but Me-Et exchange reaction will take place when mixture of MMAO and Et3Al is added at 100°C [27]. These changes of the terminal structures of the PPs indicated that a new active species “Ti-Me” was formed when MMAO was added. The species “Ti-Me” coexisted with the species “Ti-Et” in these polymerization processes. So a part of i-Bu derived from initiation reaction. As calculated from Table 4, the contents of i-Bu in different fractions PP9 (2), PP9 (3), PP9 (5) were 56mol%, 59mol% and 52mol%, respectively. That the contents of i-Bu in different fractions of PP9 were nearly equal implied three species could form “Ti-Me” species with the same content. According to Busico's interpretation of the high-resolution 13C NMR data, the atactic and isotactic polypropylene fractions comprise the same three building blocks (the configuration of the highly isotactic, isotactiod, and syndiotactic sequences being almostly invariant) and differ merely in their relative amounts [1]. We here simplified this complex issue and divided PP into three classes according to their values of MRL and crystallization behavior [19] and the catalyst systems used. The iPP3, iPP4, iPP6, iPP7 and iPP8, the fractions of boiling-heptane-insoluble, which produced by the catalysts of high stereospecificity, are conventionally referred to as isotactic polypropylene (iPP). These iPPs had values of melting point in excess of 159.9°C and values of MRL in excess of 53 repeat units, as showed in Table 2. Thus, these iPPs would be considered as prepared with highly isotactic active species (a) in Fig. 1. As showed in Fig. 2, the spectra of iPPs polymerization with Et3Al at 100°C showed the clear peaks at 38.01ppm (Sαγ), 31.06ppm (Tβδ), and 24.63ppm (Sββ) in the nearly correct 2:2:1 integration ratio. Typical structural types of PEP (P=propylene unit, E=ethylene unit) were showed in Scheme 2 and the carbon peaks associated with propylene-ethylene copolymer were assigned according to the reports [12,13,21]. A summary of the microstructure analysis of ethylene copolymerization from 13C NMR spectra was showed in Tables 5 and 6 . The peaks at 38.01ppm and 24.63ppm were due to Sαγ and Sββ of isolated ethylene units between two propylene units inserted with the same enchainment and enantioface [13,21]. These results indicated the sequence m-P n PEPP n (n ≥1) existed mainly and only a trace amount of the sequence r-PEP was detected in these iPPs. It was reported decomposition of Et3Al occurred at 100°C during the polymerization process [15–18]. The content of E in the PP chain decreased from 0.1% (iPP4 and iPP7, Al/Ti=150) to 0.015% (iPP6, Al/Ti=25) since the concentration of Et3Al decreased. The amount of catalyst of Run 6 was two times as that of Run 8. So the content of E of iPP6 was found nearly as same as that of iPP8 because they had the same concentration of Et3Al, even though the ratio of Al to Ti was different. It was worth noticing that the sequences such as P n PEEPP n and P n PEEEPP n (or EE n E) (n ≥1) of all the iPPs obtained at 100°C were found to be negligible, as showed in Table 6. The possible propylene-ethylene copolymer chain end groups formed by chain transfer reaction by alkylaluminum were showed in Fig. 3(1). As mentioned above, only two chain end groups of Et and i-Bu existed in these iPPs. This result indicated only product 3 (see Fig. 3) was formed. It implied active site 4 formed by insertion of one ethylene molecule was highly active for propylene insertion and rate of chain transfer to alkylaluminum of this active site was much slower than that of chain propagation. Because the concentration of propylene was hundreds times of that of ethylene, product 5 derived from chain transfer to alkylaluminum following ethylene insertion was too low to be detected. As showed in Tables 2 and 1, the mPP5 produced by the “simple” TiCl4MgCl2 catalyst having Cl atoms as the ligands, which had been carefully characterized by Busico’ group [9], had MRL of 46 repeat units and a DSC melting peak with the maximum at 157.4°C after crystallized at 125°C. Busico’ group [1,9] pointed out that the mPP5 should have a relatively low amount of highly isotactic blocks rather than an improbable large compatibility of the stereoerrors in the isotactoid blocks. Correa group [4] reported that for active species with Cl atoms as the ligands the ΔE stereo (a measure of the stereoselectivity of the active site [4]) value was 1.4kcal/mol while for active species with diethers or alkoxysilanes as the ligands the ΔE stereo was in the range of 3–4kcal/mol. Thus, in our opinion, mPP5 might be considered as prepared with the “isotactoid” active site (b) mainly. In addition to the sequence m-P n PEPP n detected, a trace amount of the sequence r-PEP was also detected in mPP5. The chain end group n-Pr instead of i-Bu was found in mPP5 and the molar ratio of the n-Pr/Et was ca. 0.81, as showed in Table 4. Generally chain end groups n-Pr is formed following chain transfer reactions of elimination of β-H in propylene polymerization process without hydrogen [22–24]. Taking the structures of PEP into account, it implied that n-Pr group herein resulted from ethylene copolymerization. These results indicated that only product 5 (see Fig. 3) was formed. It implied active site 4 formed by insertion of one ethylene molecule was active for propylene insertion because the mol ratio of structures of PEPs to n-Pr ca. 1. The phenomenon that product 3 was found to be negligible indicated a great increase of probability of transfer reaction of active site 4 or 7 over active site 2 or 6. This implied that occasional “one” ethylene molecule insertions remarkably slowed down propagation of propylene. The increase of the Et3Al concentration did not result in a decrease of the molecular weight for the “simple” catalyst system in our previous researches [17] while the increase of Et3Al concentration leaded to the remarkable drop of molecular weight for the other three catalyst systems in our or Kojoh group's researches [15–18,23,24]. These previous results were in accordance with the above analyses of chain ends. On the other hand, mPP5 and iPP4 were prepared with the “simple” catalyst without or with the presence of BMMF as a donor. Such a significant difference in chain end groups provided direct evidence that the suitable donor could convert species (b) to species (a). The ethylene unit in iPP9 was too low (no more than 0.005mol%) to be detected by 13C NMR because it had a very low concentration of Et3Al during the polymerization process. So PP9 (iPP9 and aPP9) was fractionated by TREF and the TREF results and characterization of the fractions of PP9 were listed in Table 7 [28]. The fraction PP9(2) which could not crystallize at 125°C was very weakly crystalline fraction and easy to form γ-PP crystal [28]. The MRL of PP9(2) was 11. Thus, this fraction might be considered as prepared with species (c) [19,29]. It was interesting that the chain end groups n-Pr, i-Bu and Et in the PP samples with different MRLs and different molecular weights had the same chemical shifts, as showed in Table 3. Thus, the influence of tacticity on chain end groups was not observed in our studies. The presence of Et, i-Bu and n-Pr in PP9(2) indicated that both products 3 and 5 (see Fig. 3) were formed. Only a trace amount of the sequence m-P n PEPP n was detected in PP9(2) and the peaks at 38.66ppm [12,13,21] (0.01mol%) and 37.81ppm [12,13,21] (0.01mol%) attributable to the sequences r-PEP appeared, as showed in Tables 5 and 6. The mol ratio of structures of PEPs to n-Pr was ca. 0.25. It indicated only a small part of the active site 4 (see Fig. 3) formed the active site 6 and most of them preferred to chain transfer reaction even though propylene of relatively high concentration was always existed in polymerization process. It was improbable that for active site 4 the chain transfer to alkylaluminum was so fast that no propylene could be inserted because generally the rate of chain propagation is far faster than the rate of chain transfer. As an example, it was reported by Chadwick group [2] that generally approximately 2–6 chain transfer reactions to alkylaluminum would occur per million monomer insertions during propylene polymerization processes with MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts. Thus, this implied that “one” ethylene molecule insertion strongly slowed down propagation of propylene. On other words, for species (c) most of active sites 4 formed by “one” ethylene molecule insertion could be viewed as “dormant” sites for propylene insertion. The polymer fraction PP9(3) had a DSC melting peak with the maximum at 150.2°C after crystallized at 125°C. The MRL of PP9(3) was 25. The mol ratio of structures of PEPs to n-Pr was ca. 0.75. It implied PP9(3) might be produced by species (b) and (c) rather than species (b) only. APP2 was the fraction of boiling-heptane-soluble obtained at 120°C. It had a DSC melting peak with the maximum at 150.0°C after crystallized at 125°C. Its MRL was 28 and its number-average molecular weight was only 1100g/mol, as showed in Table 2. This implied that aPP2 was complicated mixture of polypropylenes produced by species (c) and (b) and even (a) rather than species (c) only. Because both the polymerization temperature and the concentration of Et3Al were higher, the content of ethylene decomposed from Et3Al in Run 2 would be much higher than that in Run 9 while the content of propylene in the liquid in Run 2 would be lower than that in Run 9. It indicated the ratio of ethylene to propylene in Run 2 was much higher than that in Run 9. The complicated sequences of m-PEP, EEE, EPE and PEE were detected. The observed triad distributions of monomers of aPP2 were described in Table 6. It was interesting that r-PEPs in aPP2 were found to be negligible. However, the peak at 30.0ppm, which is attributable to carbons of Sδδ in the sequence EE n E (or P n PEEEPP n ) (n ≥1) in Scheme 2, was detected and the content of this sort of carbons was especially high (2.8mol%). The number average ethylene sequence length (n E) calculated by the following equation (1) [30] was 8. (1) n E = ( EEE + EEP + PEP ) [ PEP + 0.5 EEP ] This evidence showed the presence of a copolymer with high contents of ethylene containing very long ethylene sequences. The content of ethylene unit was about 1.8mol% in aPP2 and about 0.5mol% in all the fractions. This could be considered as copolymer produced with 0.5mol% ethylene fed. It was interesting that such a copolymer was produced with such a low ethylene concentration. Because a relatively high content of unsaturated chain end groups of Vd was found in the spectrum of aPP2, as showed in Table 4, it indicated chain transfer by elimination of β-H may play a significant role when the polymerization temperature was 120°C [16]. Thus the structure of chain end in the aPP2 was more complex than that in the PP9(2). In addition to chain end groups of Et, i-Bu, n-Pr and Vd detected in the aPP2, as showed in Table 4, the unsaturated chain end groups of isobutenyl [26] resulted from isomerization of Vd and allyl [32] were detected and the contents of these two chain end groups were 0.11mol% and 0.11mol%, respectively. Compared to PP9(2) and PP9(3), the content of n-Pr of aPP2 was very low. Furthermore the peaks at 14.04ppm and 32.20ppm appeared in the spectrum of aPP2 and the contents of these sorts of carbons were also relatively high, 0.79mol% and 0.5mol%, respectively. It indicated that the chain end groups of A and B in the Scheme 1 existed in aPP2. If all the chain end groups of A and B belong to left-end groups, one would found that the number of all left-end groups (including i-Bu, Vd, isobutenyl, allyl, Et′ and (1/2)n-Pr) would be twice as that of all right-end groups (Et and (1/2)n-Pr). It was reasonable to assume that a part of the chain end groups of A belonged to right-end groups and so a few polyethylene molecules might exist. As discussed above, the species (a) would copolymerize ethylene and propylene without an effect of the growing chain end and species (b) would copolymerize ethylene and propylene with a remarkable effect of the growing chain end. It indicated that the content of the sequence P n PEEPP n produced by species (a) should be lower than that produced by species (b). Moreover, the sequence EE n E (or P n PEEEPP n ) produced by species (a) or (b) should be too low to be detected because of such a low content of ethylene. If most of the species (c) followed by one ethylene molecule insertion were “dormant” for propylene insertion they could be “waiting” for another ethylene molecule to insert. It implied that species (c) produced copolymers with very long ethylene sequences and even polyethylene. It is well known that the reaction pathway of insertion of ethylene or propylene proposed by the Cosse–Arlman mechanism which reviewed by Brookhart and Green (cited in Boero et al. [33]) is α-agostic assisted via a tilt of the methyl group, as showed in Scheme 3 [33]. Boero et al. [33] pointed out that the growing polymer chain was oriented the regions with the lowest repulsive interactions with the ligands, whereas the propylene was oriented in such a way that it minimized the repulsions with the chain. It is also well known that isospecific insertion is apparently faster than aspecific insertion. As an example, it was reported by Chadwick group [2] that for catalyst A the values for the propagation rate coefficient (k p) for the weakly-specific sites were in the range if 35–66lmol−1 s−1 while those for isospecific sites were in the range of 234–321lmol−1 s−1. According to Busico's model, it indicates the steric stress between the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH(CH3)-CH2-CH(CH3)-P (P=polymer chain) and the ligands favors propylene insertion. Compared to the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH(CH3)-CH2-CH(CH3)-P, the chiral orientation of the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P was lost. According to Busico’ model [1] and Corradini’ model [5] and Correa’ proposal [4] and Taniike and Terano’ proposal [7], for species (a) having ligands (e.g. diethers or silanes with a steric hindrance high enough) in one or two vicinal coordination positions (see Fig. 1), rapidly highly isotactic propagation of propylene was due to the presence of steric stress between the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P and the ligands. However, for species (b) having Cl atoms as ligands in one or two of such two vicinal coordination positions, our above results implied that a decrease of steric stress between the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P and the ligands led to a significant decrease in the rate of propylene insertion. For species (c) having no ligand, the steric stress was lost and the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P was “dormant” for propylene insertion. Kissin [34] and Jordan et al. (cited in Bahri-Laleh et al. [35]) proposed that a β-agostic interaction existed in the M(Ti)-CH2-CH3 and Kissin [34] made an assumption that this interaction was stronger in the active species with a CH3 group in the β-position to the Ti atom, such as Ti-CH2-CH3 in ethylene polymerization and Ti-CH(CH3)2 in propylene polymerization. The results from ethylene and propylene polymerizations showed that this stronger β-agostic interaction in Ti-CH2-CH3 obviously slowed down ethylene insertion and this interaction in Ti-CH(CH3)2 strongly slowed down propylene insertion [34]. Recent density functional theory (DFT) calculations by Bahri-Laleh et al. [35] also confirmed this strong β-agostic interaction between the H atom of its CH3 group and the Ti atom in the species Ti-CH2-CH3 or Ti-CH(CH3). On the basis of the above theoretical results, we made an assumption that the loss of the steric stress made possible a relatively strong β-agostic interaction in the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P, as showed in Scheme 3. Such a relatively strong β-agostic interaction made the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P inactive for propylene insertion but still active for ethylene insertion. Kakugo et al. [30] proposed that random copolymer was formed on an isospecific site and Wolfsgruber et al. and Natta et al. (cited in Kakugo et al. [30]) proposed that atactic and stereoblock sites may produce copolymers with high ethylene contents and polyethylene. Xu et al. [31] pointed out a PP/PE alloy prepared with a MgCl2-supported titanium catalyst system was composed of random copolymer, multiple-block copolymer, ethylene-predominant copolymer and ethylene-propylene block copolymer. Herein we elaborated the suggestions proposed by these authors. 3.2 2,1-insertion It is well known that the propylene insertion rate is retarded at 2,1-inserted active chain ends in comparison with 1,2-inserted ones and a plausible explanation is that the 2,1-insertion will be related to the “dormant” species [34–36]. The role of hydrogen on this “dormant” species had so far been discussed by many investigators for the MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalyst [14,23–25,34–37]. Compared to the diester-based catalyst systems with the presence of an alkoxysilane donor, the diether-based catalyst systems required relatively low hydrogen concentration for effective molecular weight control. Some studies had showed that the high hydrogen response of diether-based catalyst systems can be explained by chain transfer with hydrogen after the occasional 2,1-insertion in the polymerization process [25,35–37]. As mentioned in introduction, propylene/ethylene-[1-13C] copolymerization method had been applied by Busico group [9–13] to study 2,1-insertion in propylene polymerization. They reported that when ethylene-[1-13C] was present during the polymerization reaction, the “dormant” species followed by ethylene molecule would be revived and the resulting regiomistakes in the polypropylene chains were characterized by 13C NMR. Typical structural types of two regiomistakes (“m-C” and “r-C”) were showed in Scheme 2 according to Busico’ reports [12,13]. As showed in Tables 3 and 4, the peaks at 11.36 and 19.45ppm appeared in the spectrum of PP9(2) are attributable to chain end groups of Et′ in Scheme 1 and the assignment of the chemical shifts was according to Cheng’ report [20]. This newly detected terminal group is formed by chain transfer reactions by alkylaluminum at “one” ethylene molecule insertion followed by 2-1-last-insertion, as showed in Fig. 3(2). And we assigned the peak at 35.64ppm (0.04mol%) to Sαβ in the stereosquence “r-C” in Scheme 2 according to Cheng’ [21] and Busico’ reports [12,13]. It indicated that ethylene units were flanked by two propylene units inserted with the opposite enantioface and enchainment. The ratio of Et′ to 1/2 (all the chain end groups) was ca. 12mol% and then taking into account the weight percent and number average molecular weight of each fraction, one can estimate the fraction of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit was in the 3–6mol% range. The mol percentage of the fraction of polymer soluble at room temperature (25°C) as determined by TREF method was too small (2.8mol%) to be counted. The chain end groups of Et′ and the structures of “m-C” and “r-C” were found to be negligible in PP9(3) or PP9(5). This result indicated that most of 2,1 units were concentrated in the fraction produced by species (c) in a diester-based catalyst systems. It implied that the stereosquence “r-C” was produced by species (c). It was reported by Parodi et al., Collina et al. and Chadwick et al. (cited in Busico [10]) that for a diester-based catalyst systems the distribution of 2,1 units was not uniform and most of 2,1 units were concentrated in the atactic fraction of PP. Our results were in accordance with these reports. The chain end group Et′ (0.16mol%) was also found in aPP2 and the ratio of Et′ to 1/2 (all the chain end groups) was ca. 9mol%. The peak at 34.89ppm (0.11mol%) indicated that sequence “m-c” in Scheme 2 existed, but the sequence “r-c” was found to be negligible. It indicated that ethylene units were flanked by two propylene units inserted with the same enantioface. Taking into account the weight percents of boiling-heptane-insoluble and boiling-heptane-soluble fractions and number average molecular weight of these two fractions, one can estimate the fraction of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit was in the 7–9mol% range. It was reported by Albizzati et al. (cited in Busico [10]) and Chadwick et al. [37] that for a diether-based catalyst system a significant 2,1-insertion takes place at both highly and weakly isospecific active species. It implied that the stereosquence “m-C” was produced by species (a) or (b). Busico group [9] reported both “m-c” and “r-c” existed in the fraction of boiling-heptane-soluble prepared with the “simple” catalyst and the content of “m-c” was higher than that of “r-c”. The “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites followed by ethylene insertion exhibited complex behavior in these three catalyst systems. It implied the behavior of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites depended on the nature of donors. For a diether-based or a diester-based catalyst system the mol ratio of Et′ to the structure (“r-C” or “m-C”) was no less than 1. This indicated that a large part of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites followed by “one” ethylene insertion were still “dormant” for propylene insertion at high polymerization temperature. Kojoh group reported that the activity in a diester-based catalyst system at high polymerization temperature also increased by the addition of hydrogen, but the rate of activity enhancement by hydrogen addition decreased at high polymerization temperature [24]. Obviously, only hydrogen could truly revive the dormant sites for propylene insertion. The fractions of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit were far higher than those reported by Busico group [10] because polymerization temperature herein was 100°C or 120°C which was higher than that reported by Busico group. In the end, the correlation between number-average molecular weight and the inverse of the content of chain end group (1/Cchain-end) was showed in Fig. 4 , revealing a nearly linear relationship (slope: 14.7; standard error: 1.8). So the repeat unit calculated by 13C NMR is 44.1g/mol while its theoretical value is 42g/mol. 4 Conclusions The polymerizations of propylene at 100°C or 120°C were performed with four MgCl2-supported titanium catalyst systems without H2. The polypropylenes containing a very small amount of ethylene (from 0.01 to 1.8mol%) was obtained. The copolymers with average isotactic sequence lengths exceeding 53 repeat units, which may be considered to be produced by highly isotactic species in the MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts, consisted of chain end groups of ethyl and isobutyl. The copolymer with average isotactic sequence lengths of no more than 11 repeat units, which may be considered to be produced by syndiotactic species, consisted of chain end groups of isobutyl, ethyl and n-propyl. The copolymer with average isotactic sequence lengths of 46 repeat units, which may be considered to be produced by isotactoid species, consisted of chain end groups of ethyl and n-propyl. It had been found that the active species in the MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts could be divided into three classes according to their behavior following “one” ethylene molecule insertion, which fit three-state model of active species proposed by Busico group [1] to a great degree. These results implied that most of syndiotactic species would be “dormant” for propylene insertion while highly isotactic species would remain highly active for propylene insertion when these two classes of species were inserted by “one” ethylene molecule and for syndiotactic species occasional “one” ethylene molecule insertions remarkably slowed down propagation of propylene. According to Busico’ model and Corradini’ model and Brookhart and Green’ model, these above results implied that the steric stress between the growing chain and the ligands favored the α-agostic interaction but disfavored the β-agostic interaction. Our results implied the loss of this steric stress made possible a relatively strong β-agostic interaction in the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P. Such a relatively strong β-agostic interaction made the growing chain Ti-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH(CH3)-P inactive for propylene insertion but still active for ethylene insertion. The chain end group (Et′) formed by chain transfer reactions by alkylaluminums at “one” ethylene molecule insertion followed by 2-1-last-insertion was observed in the PPs of low values of MRL. Moreover, the fraction of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit was estimated to be in the 3–6mol% range for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diester-silane catalyst while to be in the 7–9mol% range for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diether catalyst. Taking the results reported by Busico [10] into account, it implied the content of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites depended on polymerization temperature and the nature of donors and the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites formed by different active species exhibited complex behavior. 13C NMR analysis indicated that a large part of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites followed by “one” ethylene insertion were still “dormant” for propylene insertion at high polymerization temperature. coredata.dc:description: The propylene-ethylene copolymers with a very small amount of ethylene (from 0.01 to 1.8mol%) obtained with different catalyst systems at 100°C or 120°C were characterized by 13C NMR. The chain end group n-propyl formed through the chain transfer reaction of species to alkylaluminum following “one” ethylene molecule insertion was detected in these copolymers of low molecular weight. 13C NMR chain end group analysis of these copolymers implied that most of syndiotactic species in the MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts would be “dormant” for propylene insertion while highly isotactic species would remain highly active for propylene insertion when these two species were inserted by “one” ethylene molecule. For isotactoid species occasional “one” ethylene molecule insertions remarkably slowed down propagation of propylene. The active species could be divided into three classes according to their behavior following “one” ethylene molecule insertion, which fit Busico [1] three-state model of active species to a great degree. The chain end group ethyl (Et′) formed by chain transfer reactions by alkylaluminum at “one” ethylene molecule insertion followed by a 2-1-last-insertion was also detected by 13C NMR. Thus, the fraction of “dormant” polypropylene chains with a 2,1-last inserted unit was estimated to be in the 3–6mol% range for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diester-silane catalyst while for a TiCl4/MgCl2/diether catalyst the content of such the fraction was ca. 7–9mol%. 13C NMR analysis indicated that a large part of the “dormant” 2-1-inserted sites revived by “one” ethylene insertion were still “dormant” for propylene insertion at high polymerization temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Single ethylene molecular insertion as a probe into the nature of the active species in MgCl2-supported Ziegler–Natta catalysts
